poem:
Profit Slump

In the spirit glass,  
a reflection—a slump,  
whispers of tariffs  
cut like ice;  
diageo's drop  
in numbers,  
yet the amber,  
clear gin, and stout,  
persist in the flicker  
of dim bars.  
A CEO departs,  
but the pour,  
timeless,  
continues.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Guinness owner Diageo’s profits slump as it warns of $200m Trump tariff hit The world’s biggest spirits company, Diageo, has revealed a slump in annual profits and expanded its cost-cutting plan as it searches for a new boss after the resignation of the chief executive, Debra Crew. The FTSE 100 company, which owns brands including Guinness, Johnnie Walker whisky, Gordon’s gin and Smirnoff vodka, reported a nearly 28% fall in operating profit in the 12". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
